title-group.article-title: Necrotizing Sialometaplasia Within a Benign Mixed Tumor of Parotid Gland

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Pathology, University of Bologna Medical School, Bologna, Italy
2Department of Pathology, Memorial Hospital, Chattanooga, TN, USA

author-notes.corresp: Francesca Giunchi, Department of Pathology, University of Bologna Medical School, Bologna, Italy Email: frachikka@virgilio.it

body.p: Necrotizing sialometaplasia (NSM) is a benign, self-healing reactive inflammatory process of salivary glands.1 It usually involves the minor salivary glands of the oral cavity, most commonly presenting in the palate as a painful deep ulcer,2 but many other sites can be affected, including parotid gland, submandibular gland, sublingual gland, nasal cavity, maxillary sinus, buccal mucosa, tongue, retromandibular trigone, tonsil, larynx, and trachea.3 Cases with a similar morphology have also been documented in the prostate,4 lung,5 and breast.6

When involving a mucosal surface, NSM typically presents as a painful, sharply circumscribed ulcer, usually measuring 1 to 3 cm in diameter. The ulcer borders are often erythematous and may be raised. There is a wide range in the age of presentation, but most patients are older than 40 years. The pathogenesis of this lesion is thought to involve ischemia, as infarction is seen in early lesions.2 Traumatic injuries (such as dental injection, blunt forced trauma, and denture wear), alcohol and tobacco use, as well as upper respiratory infections have been implicated as potential predisposing factors. Seven cases have also been reported associated with bulimia.3 It has also been shown in association with other upper gastrointestinal disorders, such as hiatal and umbilical hernia, gastric and duodenal ulcers, esophagitis, dysphagia and vomiting after silastic ring vertical gastroplasty,7 and prolonged intubation. In the latter case, it can originate either in the trachea or in the lung.5,8

Experimental induction of squamous metaplasia in rat salivary glands has been achieved following arterial ligation, radiation, and implantation of carcinogens. Light and electron microscopic studies have shown that the main portion of the salivary gland tissue undergoing squamous metaplasia is the acinar-intercalated duct cell complex.9

Histologically, NSM is characterized by pseudoepiteliomatous hyperplasia of the overlying squamous mucosa (in particular when the lesion involves the palate); squamous metaplasia of salivary duct and acini, which may contain apoptotic cells, areas of inflammation, and mucin spillage; preservation of lobular architecture; lobular infarction with or without mucin spillage; and ischemic lobular necrosis of seromucinous glands (see Figures 1 and 2).2,3

caption.p: Necrotizing sialometaplasia in the left parotid gland in a 61-year-old female. The lesion was present in a myoepithelial cell-rich benign mixed tumor. Salivary ducts with squamous metaplasia and pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia surround a necrotic center that has been largely replaced by hyalinized connective tissue
(A and B) Medium-power and high-power views of necrotizing sialometaplasia. The lesion simulates an invasive squamous cell carcinoma

body.p: Some cases have been described in association with salivary gland tumors, in particular Warthin’s tumor and oncocytoma.10-13 The mechanism for this change is unknown. Possibly the extravasation of mucinous secretion or cyst contents may result in the reactive changes observed.10 Some cases of NSM (particular in Warthin’s tumor) have occurred adjacent to areas of infarction.11 Sometimes NDM follows fine needle aspiration or biopsy, an infection, or previous radiotherapy.12

Squamous cell metaplasia at the edge of tumor necrosis can show a reactive epithelial proliferation with pseudoinfiltrative extension into the surrounding tissue, so that a squamous cell carcinoma is simulated. Occasionally there is a focal development of goblet cells, a finding that can be confused with mucoepidermoid carcinoma. This pseudoneoplastic proliferation with stellate extension into the surrounding tissue could result in a false diagnosis of squamous cells carcinoma.14 Reactive squamous epithelium can be alarmingly atypical, with the presence of single-cell necrosis. Immunohistochemistry has been attempted as a diagnostic aid, especially when confronted with scanty biopsy material.3 In particular, the extensive expression of CK 7 staining and the positivity for calponin and SMA in residual myoepithelial cells at the periphery of the solid squamous islands may be helpful.2

No specific measure is necessary for NSM, other than reassuring the patient of the benign nature of the lesion, although resolution is often slow. The main importance of this lesion lies in the fact that is can be confused with a squamous cell carcinoma.
